data.title: The Right to Life (1917)
data.meta_description: A young girl marries a financier knowing he has only a short time to live, so she can inherit his money.Her lover, who has made a fortune away in America, returns and wants to hasten the financier's death.
data.text:
Lost Film.

From Kevin Brownlow's "The Parade's Gone By":

"Le Droit à la Vie [The Right to Life] was a melodrama with strong psychological overtones, retaining nevertheless the basis of a thriller. A financier, suffering from an incurable illness, falls in love with a young girl, who marries him knowing he has only a short time to live. She consents to this sacrifice in order to obtain his fortune and, later, to marry her lover. But the lover has made his own fortune, in America, and when he returns, tensions mount, culminating in the attempted murder of the financier. A crime passionel charge is cleared by the wounded financier, who unites the two lovers before he eventually dies.

Le Droit…
